Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
Chapter 19, Section 3: Contemplation of Practice, Part 1
At that time, SubhÅ«ti again replied to ÅšÄriputra, saying:
As the Venerable One has said, 'What is meant by contemplating all dharmas?'
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate form as neither permanent nor impermanent, and they contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither permanent nor impermanent;
They contemplate form as neither blissful nor suffering, and they contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither blissful nor suffering;

They contemplate form as neither self nor non-self, and they contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither self nor non-self;ğŸ”½They contemplate form as neither pure nor impure, and they contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither pure nor impure;
They contemplate form as neither empty nor not empty, and they contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate form as neither having characteristics nor not having characteristics, contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither having characteristics nor not having characteristics;
Contemplate form as neither having vows nor not having vows, contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither having vows nor not having vows;
Contemplate form as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;
Contemplate form as neither apart from nor not apart from, contemplate feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness as neither apart from nor not apart from.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the eye sense base as neither permanent nor impermanent, they contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases as neither permanent nor impermanent;
They contemplate the eye sense base as neither blissful nor suffering, they contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases as neither blissful nor suffering;
Contemplate the eye sense field as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields as neither self nor non-self;
Contemplate the eye sense field as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields as neither pure nor impure;
Contemplate the eye sense field as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields as neither empty nor not empty;
Contemplate the eye sense field as neither having marks nor being without marks, and contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields as neither having marks nor being without marks;

Contemplate the eye sense field as neither having wishes nor being without wishes, and contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields as neither having wishes nor being without wishes;
Contemplate the eye sense field as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, and contemplate the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense fields as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;
Contemplate the eye-base as neither secluded nor not secluded, contemplate the ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, and mind-bases as neither secluded nor not secluded.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the form-base as neither permanent nor impermanent, they contemplate the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma-bases as neither permanent nor impermanent;
They contemplate the form-base as neither blissful nor suffering, they contemplate the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma-bases as neither blissful nor suffering;

They contemplate the form-base as neither self nor non-self, they contemplate the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma-bases as neither self nor non-self;ğŸ”½They contemplate the form-base as neither pure nor impure, they contemplate the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma-bases as neither pure nor impure;
They contemplate the form-base as neither empty nor not empty, they contemplate the sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharma-bases as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the sense field of sights as neither having characteristics nor not having characteristics, contemplate sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and mental phenomena as neither having characteristics nor not having characteristics;

Contemplate the sense field of sights as neither having aspirations nor not having aspirations, contemplate sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and mental phenomena as neither having aspirations nor not having aspirations;
Contemplate the sense field of sights as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, contemplate sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and mental phenomena as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;
Contemplate the sense field of sights as neither isolated nor not isolated, contemplate sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and mental phenomena as neither isolated nor not isolated.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they contemplate the eye constituent as neither permanent nor impermanent, they contemplate the form constituent, eye consciousness constituent, and eye contact and the various sensations produced from the condition of eye contact as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither happy nor suffering, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as neither happy nor suffering;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither self nor non-self, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as neither self nor non-self;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither pure nor impure, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither empty nor not empty, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the various feelings that arise from eye-contact as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither with vows nor without vows, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the feelings produced from eye-contact as neither with vows nor without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the eye-element as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the feelings produced from eye-contact as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;

Contemplate the eye-element as neither isolated nor not isolated, contemplate the form-element, eye-consciousness-element, and eye-contact, and the feelings produced from eye-contact as neither isolated nor not isolated.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the ear-element as neither permanent nor impermanent, they contemplate the sound-element, ear-consciousness-element, and ear-contact, and the feelings produced from ear-contact as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate the ear realm as neither pleasant nor unpleasant, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact as neither pleasant nor unpleasant;

Contemplate the ear realm as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact as neither self nor non-self;
Contemplate the ear realm as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate the ear realm as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the ear realm as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, ear contact, and the feelings that arise from ear contact as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;

Contemplate the ear realm as neither with vows nor without vows, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, and ear contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of ear contact as neither with vows nor without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the ear realm as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, and ear contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of ear contact as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;

Contemplate the ear realm as neither isolated nor not isolated, and contemplate the sound realm, ear consciousness realm, and ear contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of ear contact as neither isolated nor not isolated.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the nose realm as neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate the smell realm, nose consciousness realm, and nose contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of nose contact as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate the nose sense-sphere as neither pleasant nor unpleasant, and contemplate the olfactory sense-sphere, olfactory consciousness-sphere, olfactory contact, and the feelings produced by olfactory contact as neither pleasant nor unpleasant;

Contemplate the nose sense-sphere as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the olfactory sense-sphere, olfactory consciousness-sphere, olfactory contact, and the feelings produced by olfactory contact as neither self nor non-self;

Contemplate the nose sense-sphere as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the olfactory sense-sphere, olfactory consciousness-sphere, olfactory contact, and the feelings produced by olfactory contact as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate the nose sense-sphere as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the olfactory sense-sphere, olfactory consciousness-sphere, olfactory contact, and the feelings produced by olfactory contact as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the nose sense-sphere as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, and contemplate the olfactory sense-sphere, olfactory consciousness-sphere, olfactory contact, and the feelings produced by olfactory contact as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;

Contemplate the nose sense field as neither with vows nor without vows, and contemplate the olfactory sense field, olfactory consciousness, and olfactory contact and what is produced by olfactory contact as neither with vows nor without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the nose sense field as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, and contemplate the olfactory sense field, olfactory consciousness, and olfactory contact and what is produced by olfactory contact as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;

Contemplate the nose sense field as neither isolated nor not isolated, and contemplate the olfactory sense field, olfactory consciousness, and olfactory contact and what is produced by olfactory contact as neither isolated nor not isolated.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they contemplate the tongue sense field as neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate the taste sense field, tongue consciousness, and taste contact and what is produced by taste contact as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate the tongue element as neither blissful nor painful, and contemplate the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact as neither blissful nor painful;

Contemplate the tongue element as neither a self nor not a self, and contemplate the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact as neither a self nor not a self;

Contemplate the tongue element as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate the tongue element as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the tongue element as neither having a mark nor not having a mark, and contemplate the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of tongue contact as neither having a mark nor not having a mark;

Contemplate that the tongue element is neither with-outflows nor without-outflows, and contemplate that the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings that arise from tongue contact as a condition are neither with-outflows nor without-outflows;ğŸ”½Contemplate that the tongue element is neither calm nor not calm, and contemplate that the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings that arise from tongue contact as a condition are neither calm nor not calm;

Contemplate that the tongue element is neither isolated nor not isolated, and contemplate that the taste element, tongue consciousness element, tongue contact, and the feelings that arise from tongue contact as a condition are neither isolated nor not isolated.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they contemplate that the body element is neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate that the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings that arise from body contact as a condition are neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate the body element as neither pleasant nor unpleasant, and contemplate the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of body contact as neither pleasant nor unpleasant;

Contemplate the body element as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of body contact as neither self nor non-self;

Contemplate the body element as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of body contact as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate the body element as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of body contact as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the body element as neither having characteristics nor not having characteristics, and contemplate the touch element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings produced from the condition of body contact as neither having characteristics nor not having characteristics;

Contemplate the body element as neither with-outflows nor without-outflows, and contemplate the tactile objects element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as neither with-outflows nor without-outflows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the body element as neither calm nor not calm, and contemplate the tactile objects element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as neither calm nor not calm;

Contemplate the body element as neither isolated nor not isolated, and contemplate the tactile objects element, body consciousness element, body contact, and the feelings that arise from the condition of body contact as neither isolated nor not isolated.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they contemplate the mind element as neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate the dharma element, mind consciousness element, mind contact, and the feelings that arise from the condition of mind contact as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate the realm of mind as neither pleasant nor unpleasant, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither pleasant nor unpleasant;

Contemplate the realm of mind as neither self nor non-self, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither self nor non-self;

Contemplate the realm of mind as neither pure nor impure, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate the realm of mind as neither empty nor not empty, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the realm of mind as neither with characteristics nor without characteristics, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither with characteristics nor without characteristics;

Contemplate the realm of the mind as neither with vows nor without vows, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither with vows nor without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the realm of the mind as neither calm nor not calm, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither calm nor not calm;

Contemplate the realm of the mind as neither secluded nor not secluded, contemplate the realm of dharmas, the mind consciousness realm, and the mental contact and mental contact-born feelings as neither secluded nor not secluded.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the earth element as neither permanent nor impermanent, they contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither permanent nor impermanent;
Contemplate the earth element as neither happiness nor suffering, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither happiness nor suffering;
Contemplate the earth element as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither self nor non-self;
Contemplate the earth element as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither pure nor impure;
Contemplate the earth element as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the earth element as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;

Contemplate the earth element as neither having aspirations nor being without aspirations, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither having aspirations nor being without aspirations;
Contemplate the earth element as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;
Contemplate the earth element as neither apart nor not apart, and contemplate the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements as neither apart nor not apart.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path as neither permanent nor impermanent;
They contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither blissful nor painful, and contemplate the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path as neither blissful nor painful;

They contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path as neither self nor non-self;ğŸ”½They contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path as neither pure nor impure;
They contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the noble truths of the accumulation, cessation, and path as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, contemplate the noble truths of the origin, cessation, and path as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;
Contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither having vows nor being without vows, contemplate the noble truths of the origin, cessation, and path as neither having vows nor being without vows;
Contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, contemplate the noble truths of the origin, cessation, and path as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;
Contemplate the noble truth of suffering as neither secluded nor not secluded, contemplate the noble truths of the origin, cessation, and path as neither secluded nor not secluded.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they contemplate ignorance as neither permanent nor impermanent, they contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and anguish as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate ignorance as neither happy nor unhappy, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither happy nor unhappy;

Contemplate ignorance as neither self nor not self, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither self nor not self;ğŸ”½Contemplate ignorance as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate ignorance as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate ignorance as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;

Contemplate ignorance as neither having vows nor being without vows, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither having vows nor being without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate ignorance as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;ğŸ”½Contemplate ignorance as neither secluded nor not secluded, and contemplate formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress as neither secluded nor not secluded.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called observing all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they observe inner emptiness as neither permanent nor impermanent, and they observe outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of inherent existence, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of non-existence as neither permanent nor impermanent;

Contemplate inner emptiness as neither blissful nor painful, and contemplate outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature as neither blissful nor painful;

Contemplate inner emptiness as neither a self nor not a self, and contemplate outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature as neither a self nor not a self;

Contemplate inner emptiness as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, emptiness of ultimate reality, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, emptiness of the absolute, emptiness of the beginningless and endless, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate inner emptiness as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, emptiness of ultimate reality, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, emptiness of the absolute, emptiness of the beginningless and endless, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature as neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate inner emptiness as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics, and contemplate outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, emptiness of ultimate reality, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, emptiness of the absolute, emptiness of the beginningless and endless, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature as neither having characteristics nor being without characteristics;

Contemplate inner emptiness as neither having aspirations nor being without aspirations, and contemplate outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, emptiness of ultimate reality, emptiness of conditioned phenomena, emptiness of unconditioned phenomena, emptiness of the absolute, emptiness of the beginningless and endless, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of intrinsic nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all phenomena, emptiness of non-apprehension, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature as neither having aspirations nor being without aspirations;

Contemplate that internal emptiness is neither tranquil nor not tranquil, and contemplate that external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all dharmas, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature are neither tranquil nor not tranquil;

Contemplate that internal emptiness is neither separation nor non-separation, and contemplate that external emptiness, internal and external emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, great emptiness, ultimate emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, absolute emptiness, emptiness without beginning or end, emptiness of dispersion, emptiness of immutability, emptiness of inherent nature, emptiness of specific characteristics, emptiness of common characteristics, emptiness of all dharmas, emptiness of non-attainment, emptiness of nature, emptiness of self-nature, and emptiness of the nature of self-nature are neither separation nor non-separation.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the perfection of giving as neither permanent nor impermanent, and they contemplate the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom as neither permanent nor impermanent;

they contemplate the perfection of giving as neither blissful nor suffering, and they contemplate the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom as neither blissful nor suffering;
they contemplate the perfection of giving as neither self nor non-self, and they contemplate the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom as neither self nor non-self;
they contemplate the perfection of giving as neither pure nor impure, and they contemplate the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom as neither pure nor impure;

Contemplate that the perfection of giving is neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate that the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom are neither empty nor not empty;

Contemplate that the perfection of giving has neither marks nor no marks, and contemplate that the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom have neither marks nor no marks;ğŸ”½Contemplate that the perfection of giving is neither with vows nor without vows, and contemplate that the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom are neither with vows nor without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate that the perfection of giving is neither calm nor not calm, and contemplate that the perfections of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom are neither calm nor not calm;

Contemplate the perfection of giving as neither separation nor non-separation, and contemplate the perfection of morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom as neither separation nor non-separation.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they contemplate the four concentrations as neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate the four immeasurables and four formless concentrations as neither permanent nor impermanent;
They contemplate the four concentrations as neither blissful nor suffering, and contemplate the four immeasurables and four formless concentrations as neither blissful nor suffering;
They contemplate the four concentrations as neither self nor non-self, and contemplate the four immeasurables and four formless concentrations as neither self nor non-self;
They contemplate the four concentrations as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the four immeasurables and four formless concentrations as neither pure nor impure;
Contemplate the four formless concentrations as neither empty nor not empty;
Contemplate the four immeasurables and four formless concentrations as neither with characteristics nor without characteristics;
Contemplate the four formless concentrations as neither with vows nor without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the four formless concentrations as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;
Contemplate the four formless concentrations as neither secluded nor not secluded.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called contemplating all dharmas.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, they contemplate the eight liberations as neither permanent nor impermanent, and contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither permanent nor impermanent;

They contemplate the eight liberations as neither blissful nor suffering, and contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither blissful nor suffering;

They contemplate the eight liberations as neither with self nor without self, and contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither with self nor without self;
They contemplate the eight liberations as neither pure nor impure, and contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither pure nor impure;

They contemplate the eight liberations as neither empty nor not empty, and contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither empty nor not empty;

They contemplate the eight liberations as neither with characteristics nor without characteristics, and contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither with characteristics nor without characteristics;

Contemplate the eight liberations as neither having vows nor being without vows, contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither having vows nor being without vows;ğŸ”½Contemplate the eight liberations as neither tranquil nor not tranquil, contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither tranquil nor not tranquil;

Contemplate the eight liberations as neither secluded nor not secluded, contemplate the eight superior realms, nine sequential concentrations, and ten universal bases as neither secluded nor not secluded.
ÅšÄriputra!
